div1.p: In the United States Circuit Court for the Western District of Washington. Northern Division
In the Matter of the Petition of Joseph Walton for a writ of habeas corpus.
Filed U.S. Circuit Court, Western District of Washington. NOV 20 1909. A. Reeves Ayres, Clerk
Frederic C. Dorety. Attorney for Petitioner
In the United States Circuit Court, For the Western District of Washington, Northern Division
In the Matter of the Petition of Joseph Walton for a writ of habeas corpus. No. 1376. Order Remanding Petitioner

The petition herein for a writ of habeas corpus coming on for hearing, and it appearing from said petition and from the return of L. C. Smith thereto that said L. C. Smith was Sheriff of King County, State of Washington, and that said petitioner was being held by said L. C. Smith as such Sheriff under a warrant duly issued in form provided by law for the arrest of petitioner for violation of a certain Act of the Legislatre of the State of Washington, entitled "An Act to prohibit the carrying on of the business of barbering on Sunday, and providing a penalty for the violation thereof," approved March 7, 1903; it having been alleged in said petition and denied in said return that said Act was unconstitutional and constituted no justification for said arrest; and said petitioner having been produced before the court upon the 15th day of January, 1906, and the court having fully considered the law and the evidence, and it appearing that said Act is legal and constitutional, and that said petitioner is under arrest duly charged with a crime committed in violation of said Act,

NOW, THEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED ADJUDGED AND DECREED that said petitioner, Joseph Walton, be remanded to the custody of said L. C. Smith, as Sheriff of King County, and that upon the appearance of said Joseph Walton, and upon his surrendering himself into the custody of the United States Marshal for delivery into the custody of said L. C. Smith as aforesaid, the recognizance heretofore executed by said petitioner for his
appearance in this action may be released and discharged. Done in open court, this 20th day of Nov. 1909.
